ğŸ§  Deep Dive: From Notification Failure to Protocol Insight â€“ Debugging SCTP_SEND_FAILEDIn this post, I walk through a subtle but critical SCTP issue that emerged when handling SCTP_SEND_FAILED notifications â€” exploring how low-level socket events, memory layout, and system-generated notification structures like sctp_send_failed reveal the real root cause behind failed datagram delivery in production.ğŸ” Unpacking SCTP_SEND_FAILED: From Kernel Notification to Root CauseIn SCTP-based communication systems, handling failure gracefully is as critical as achieving successful transmission. This post traces a real-world debugging session triggered by a recurring SCTP_SEND_FAILED notification â€” often dismissed as a low-level socket error, but here unpacked layer by layer to reveal deep transport-level insights.We begin at the point of failure: a datagram silently dropped, triggering a structured SCTP notification. Using sctp_send_failed and its fields (ssf_type, ssf_flags, ssf_error, and ssf_info), we decode the kernel's message about why the send operation couldn't complete. We show how to safely extract this information from a raw notification buffer, interpret the semantics of each field, and map it back to application-layer intent.To go deeper, we captured traffic with Wireshark and discovered a critical clue: a heartbeat message sent from a Docker container to our system, which unexpectedly led to the abortion of the SCTP association. This insight helped correlate the SCTP_SEND_FAILED with external traffic patterns, uncovering the real trigger â€” an out-of-band heartbeat interpreted as a protocol violation or arriving during a teardown state.By analyzing memory handling, buffer reuse, and edge-case protocol behavior (like full receive queues or association termination), we arrived at a concrete cause â€” often buried deep beneath user-facing symptoms. This is a story of system-level observability, correct struct alignment, and mastering the contract between user space and kernel through precise data interpretation.Ideal for engineers working with SCTP, E2AP, or any protocol stack that depends on robust notification handling.Iâ€™d be glad to collaborate on any projects in the fields of telecommunications systems, wireless networks, network protocols, or low-level programming. If you believe my experience and skills can contribute to your work, Iâ€™d be more than happy to be part of your team â€” even in a small role.

Balancing work and personal life is no easy task.Even with a carefully planned to-do list, thereâ€™s always something left unchecked, a call to return, a workout missed, or a hobby postponed.As someone working a full-time remote job, Iâ€™ve experienced both sides of the coin.Many assume remote work is all about comfort, no commute, flexible hours, more time with family. And yes, it is a blessing in many ways.But it can also be mentally exhausting.When your home is your office, the lines blur. You start replying to emails during dinner, attending meetings from your living room, and slowly, your personal space starts to shrink.Still, I wouldnâ€™t trade the flexibility and freedom for anything.There are many pros and cons of having a WFH job:Pros:âœ“ No daily commuteâœ“ Better focus (most days!)âœ“ More family timeCons:â€¢ Isolation at timesâ€¢ Work-life boundaries blurâ€¢ Harder to "switch off"Hereâ€™s what helps me in making my remote job more effective:** Setting clear working hours** Taking breaks seriously (Because rest is also important to improve productivity)** Creating a separate workspace (Most helpful)** Logging off without guilt Working remotely isnâ€™t always easy â€” but itâ€™s definitely a privilege when balanced right.How do you manage work-life balance while working remotely?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#Productivity hashtag#WFH hashtag#MentalWellness hashtag#LinkedInPost

One of the most common myths of delocalized work is that coworkers never meet in person. Based on my own experience leading remote teams during my tenure at Microsoft, there are no substitute for meeting face to face with team members. It is actually one of the key elements to make distributed companies work! The meetings are planned and structured to allow people to come together in a way that facilitates connections in working environments where face to face time is not a continuous activity like in an office, but a well prepared and periodical activity.

Introducing Wizzy â€” a surveillance and patrolling robot I developed as part of my Tinker Lab project, designed to work in environments where traditional CCTV systems fall short.Wizzy is more than just a mobile bot. Itâ€™s a self-thinking, self-correcting system powered by a Raspberry Pi 4 â€” capable of intelligent patrolling, real-time decision-making, and remote monitoring. Built with flexibility and scalability in mind, Wizzy is ideal for warehouses, mid-sized factories, or secure zones where both movement and memory matter.What makes Wizzy tick:1) Smart Patrol System: Avoids getting stuck, detects patterns, and makes decisions based on sensor input2) Memory of previous states and paths: Reduces repeated loops and improves efficiency over time3) Remote Surveillance: Includes a web dashboard for manual control and camera feed access4) Real-time camera monitoring: Captures and transmits visual data during patrol5) Modular codebase: Clean Python code with multithreading and behavior modelingUnder the hood: Wizzyâ€™s core logic is written in Python, using multithreading for non-blocking patrol control. The SmartPatrol engine implements a stateful decision system â€” analyzing IR sensor inputs to detect obstacles, identify stuck loops, and dynamically choose optimal turn directions. It uses pattern history (via deques), state memory, and an adaptive escape mechanism to enhance area coverage. Motion control, decision branches, and environmental feedback are abstracted for flexibility and reusability.The entire project is open-source and available here: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dY4KyM3BThis started as a college submission â€” but I see it as the first step toward practical, deployable surveillance robotics.hashtag#Robotics hashtag#Automation hashtag#Surveillance hashtag#RaspberryPi hashtag#PythonProjects hashtag#CollegeProjects hashtag#SmartSecurity hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WizzyBot hashtag#OpenSource

Here's my latest JavaFX project. The famous card game locally known as 'Daketti'.After often playing with friends till late night, I thought why not code it?Here's are its main featuresâ¡ï¸Played between four players with two in each team.â¡ï¸Game starts with 4 cards in hand of each player and 4 cards in center.â¡ï¸Excessive use of List and Stack data structures.â¡ï¸JavaFX Transition classes for animation.â¡ï¸Use of OOP principles for a scalable structure.â¡ï¸Game result calculation in the end.Currently it is played on a single PC. Future plans are to make it playable on LAN on 4 PC's using java socket programming. Also the code design focuses on all 4 OOP principles, so I have a plan to add some other card games in the collection like (local names) 'Thula', 'Bluff', etc.

What Was Patch Update 1.2.1? In our web application, version numbers carry a lot of meaning. A â€œpatchâ€ releaseâ€”in this case, 1.2.1â€”signals small but important fixes, rather than brand-new features or breaking changes. Patch 1.2.1 addressed several usability issues and visual inconsistencies that cropped up after the last minor release (1.2.0). Below is a breakdown of what we tackled and why it matters.Distinguishing This Patch from a Full Release Unlike a major or minor release, Patch 1.2.1 did not introduce new workflows or API endpoints. Instead, it focused on smoothing out rough edges in the user interface and ensuring that existing functionality behaved predictably, even under unusual conditions.1. Fixed Language Selector IssuesğŸ‘‰ Only Complete Translations Shown We now limit the dropdown to languages with full translation sets: English, Spanish, and French.ğŸ‘‰ Robust Error Handling Unsupported or partial translations no longer trigger crashes; the selector gracefully handles missing files.ğŸ‘‰ English Fallback If a userâ€™s last-selected language is removed (for example, during maintenance), the app automatically reverts to English until a supported locale is chosen.2. Added Icon-Only Behavior on ScrollğŸ‘‰ Consistent â€œStickyâ€ Behavior Much like the GitHub header, the language selector now collapses to its icon when you scroll down, freeing up space without losing accessibility.ğŸ‘‰ Improved Visibility The icon-only mode prevents the selector from obscuring content during long scrolling sessions, providing a cleaner reading experience.3. Created a Dedicated Patch Update PageğŸ‘‰ Centralized Patch Notes We spun up a new â€œPatch Updateâ€ page that documents every detail of this release in one place.ğŸ‘‰ Footer Link Access A permanently visible link in the site footer ensures you can always find the latest patch notes without hunting through changelogs.4. Improved Color ConsistencyğŸ‘‰ Theme Alignment All elements on the patch update page now adhere to our established color palette.ğŸ‘‰ CSS Variable Adoption By switching to CSS variables, future color tweaks will propagate site-wide, reducing the likelihood of mismatched hues.5. Updated DocumentationğŸ‘‰ CHANGELOG We recorded every fix and tweak under â€œ1.2.1â€ so you can trace our work from start to finish.ğŸ‘‰ Version Bump package.json now reflects the new version numberâ€”1.2.1â€”so our dependency managers and CI pipelines stay in sync.Read more here: https://lnkd.in/dRCwbFJu

Hereâ€™s a game-changer for delivering exceptional customer service: **"Listen first, solve second."** In a digital world, customers crave genuine connection. Before jumping to solutions: âœ” **Acknowledge their concern** â€“ "I understand how frustrating this must be." âœ” **Clarify before assuming** â€“ "Just to confirm, are you facing [specific issue]?" âœ” **Then, resolve with confidence.** Why? Because people donâ€™t just want fixesâ€”they want to feel *heard*. **Pro Remote Bonus:** Use short, empathetic voice notes (when appropriate) to add a human touch to written chats. ğŸ™ï¸ Whatâ€™s your go-to remote customer service tip? Diving Deep into OpenThread Architecture forÂ STM32WB

"Yes, I still program in C when necessary. Why? Speed. And because it talks natively to the OS."Let me explain with a real-world example:I recently built a real-time WebSocket server to act as a multiplexer for users across multiple connectionsâ€”similar to how WhatsApp syncs messages between your phone and desktop browser in real-time.âœ… When a message is sent or received, it broadcasts instantly to all connected devices.âœ… But the challenge? The core project was in PHPâ€”and I needed real-time messaging without switching stacks.I tried PHP CLI to build the server, but hit a wall:â€¢ No official multithreading supportâ€¢ I had to rely on fork()â€”which creates a new process (slow & resource-heavy)â€¢ And worse: sockets couldnâ€™t be shared across processesHereâ€™s the problem:Imagine your phone is connected on Process A, your laptop on Process B.When a message arrives for your phone, Process A canâ€™t access Process Bâ€™s socket to forward it.Thatâ€™s when I turned to C.With C:â€¢ I implemented threads (sharing resources within a single process)â€¢ The socket file descriptors remained accessible across threadsâ€¢ I could handle each connection in its own thread, linked to the authenticated userHow? ğŸ‘‰ I implemented the RFC 6455 WebSocket spec for the handshake ğŸ‘‰ Then authenticated each connection by calling back to the PHP app (using the HTTP cookie) ğŸ‘‰ PHP responded with a success status and user ID, which I used to track connectionsThe result: a blazing fast, multi-threaded WebSocket server written in C, integrated seamlessly with PHP.In my next post, Iâ€™ll cover how I used IPC to connect C and PHP, and how I grouped connections in a hashmap + linked list for efficient broadcasting.ğŸ‘‰ Curious about the challenges of mixing C and PHP in real-time systems? Letâ€™s talkâ€”drop your questions below!hashtag#SystemDesign hashtag#PHP hashtag#C hashtag#Linux hashtag#WebSocket

Working with watchdog timers in RTOS systems brings interesting challenges.The basic idea is simple: the watchdog counts down and resets the system if itâ€™s not reloaded in time useful to detect infinite loops or system hangs.But in multitask systems with different deadlines (e.g., one task running every 10ms, another every 100ms), feeding the watchdog from each task becomes unreliable and messy (due to timing and concurrency issues).Some alternatives Iâ€™ve explored: - Idle-priority task feeding: Since the feeder task has the lowest priority, if any higher-priority task hangs, the watchdog wonâ€™t be fed and will eventually reset the system. - Task notification system: Each task sends an â€œIâ€™m aliveâ€ signal to a watchdog monitor. If one fails, you can react more precisely, like restart only the faulty task if a full system reset isnâ€™t necessary.While reading the hashtag#ZephyrRTOS docs, i've found a great solution called Task Watchdog:It uses kernel software timers to monitor tasks and can trigger custom callback functions when a task fails to reset its own timer. We can define per-task deadlines and recovery behavior, and still fall back to the hardware watchdog if needed.I might try this feature in my Zephyr-based cruise control system if I get the time, and if so, Iâ€™ll share some of the results.

Java 24 just dropped, and I took some of my saturday to dig into the changes compared to Java 23... And I have to say, itâ€™s a solid update. One of the things I was really looking forward to was the finalization of the Foreign Function & Memory API, it basically gives Java a safe, high-performance way to interact with native code and memory, without all the clunky, error creator boilerplate of JNI. You can now allocate off-heap memory, call native libraries, and work with memory segments almost like you're in C, but with Java safety.. I also appreciate how Java 24 is going fr preview features, like unnamed variables and patterns, not sure if they are really usefull, but I like previews, lets test it.On the tooling and performance side, the improvements to the JIT compiler and the enhancements to garbage collection are things I started seeing the impact in some memory-heavy workloads. It feels like Java is becoming a more modern language without losing what made it so stable and reliable in the first place. Iâ€™m still cautious about adopting preview features in production, but I like where things are going, itâ€™s like Java is shaking off some of its old weight while staying rock-solid for enterprise apps. Iâ€™ll definitely be using Java 24 for side projects just to explore everything more deeply.Oh, almost forgot to mention, if you wanna test the previews, use this:--enable-preview If youâ€™re using intelij, like me, youâ€™ll also need to enable preview features in the project settings.

DPDK, eBPF, and XDP: Their Crucial Roles in Virtual NetworkingIn virtual networking, DPDK, eBPF, and XDP each offer distinct advantages for optimizing performance, security, and observability. DPDK excels in high-performance, low-latency packet processing by bypassing the kernel, making it ideal for user-space network functions like virtual switches (OVS-DPDK) and virtual network functions (VNFs), where throughput and customizability are critical. eBPF, running in the kernel, enables efficient network observability, security policy enforcement, and deep packet inspection with minimal overhead. It is often integrated into Kubernetes CNI plugins like Cilium and Calico for network visibility and microsegmentation. XDP, built on top of eBPF, provides ultra-fast ingress filtering by executing programs directly at the NIC driver level, making it ideal for early packet filtering and load balancing, which reduces network congestion and latency in multi-tenant environments. Together, these technologies power modern cloud-native networks, providing high performance, flexible security, and granular control, particularly in virtualized environments like Kubernetes and NFV architectures.1. DPDKIdeal for virtual switches, VNFs, and edge compute gateways.Enables performance similar to hardware appliances.Extensively used in OpenStack and telecom NFV solutions.2. eBPF Powers Cilium, Tetragon, and other Kubernetes CNIs and observability tools.Integrates with Linux namespaces, cgroups, containers, and VMs.Extensible without kernel patches, supporting zero-trust security models.Limited performance vs DPDK in raw throughput.3. XDFIdeal for DDOS mitigation, early firewalling, and L4 load balancing.Reduces load on host networking stack yet important in multi-tenant environments.Limited programmability compared to full eBPF (no loops, tight instruction budget).Widely used in Cilium, Facebook Katran, and cloud CNI pipelines.hashtag#DPDK hashtag#eBPF hashtag#XDP hashtag#Cilium hashtag#Katran hashtag#CNI hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Tetragon hashtag#OVS

ğŸ§  Deep Dive: From Notification Failure to Protocol Insight â€“ Debugging SCTP_SEND_FAILEDIn this post, I walk through a subtle but critical SCTP issue that emerged when handling SCTP_SEND_FAILED notifications â€” exploring how low-level socket events, memory layout, and system-generated notification structures like sctp_send_failed reveal the real root cause behind failed datagram delivery in production.ğŸ” Unpacking SCTP_SEND_FAILED: From Kernel Notification to Root CauseIn SCTP-based communication systems, handling failure gracefully is as critical as achieving successful transmission. This post traces a real-world debugging session triggered by a recurring SCTP_SEND_FAILED notification â€” often dismissed as a low-level socket error, but here unpacked layer by layer to reveal deep transport-level insights.We begin at the point of failure: a datagram silently dropped, triggering a structured SCTP notification. Using sctp_send_failed and its fields (ssf_type, ssf_flags, ssf_error, and ssf_info), we decode the kernel's message about why the send operation couldn't complete. We show how to safely extract this information from a raw notification buffer, interpret the semantics of each field, and map it back to application-layer intent.To go deeper, we captured traffic with Wireshark and discovered a critical clue: a heartbeat message sent from a Docker container to our system, which unexpectedly led to the abortion of the SCTP association. This insight helped correlate the SCTP_SEND_FAILED with external traffic patterns, uncovering the real trigger â€” an out-of-band heartbeat interpreted as a protocol violation or arriving during a teardown state.By analyzing memory handling, buffer reuse, and edge-case protocol behavior (like full receive queues or association termination), we arrived at a concrete cause â€” often buried deep beneath user-facing symptoms. This is a story of system-level observability, correct struct alignment, and mastering the contract between user space and kernel through precise data interpretation.Ideal for engineers working with SCTP, E2AP, or any protocol stack that depends on robust notification handling.Iâ€™d be glad to collaborate on any projects in the fields of telecommunications systems, wireless networks, network protocols, or low-level programming. If you believe my experience and skills can contribute to your work, Iâ€™d be more than happy to be part of your team â€” even in a small role.

Balancing work and personal life is no easy task.Even with a carefully planned to-do list, thereâ€™s always something left unchecked, a call to return, a workout missed, or a hobby postponed.As someone working a full-time remote job, Iâ€™ve experienced both sides of the coin.Many assume remote work is all about comfort, no commute, flexible hours, more time with family. And yes, it is a blessing in many ways.But it can also be mentally exhausting.When your home is your office, the lines blur. You start replying to emails during dinner, attending meetings from your living room, and slowly, your personal space starts to shrink.Still, I wouldnâ€™t trade the flexibility and freedom for anything.There are many pros and cons of having a WFH job:Pros:âœ“ No daily commuteâœ“ Better focus (most days!)âœ“ More family timeCons:â€¢ Isolation at timesâ€¢ Work-life boundaries blurâ€¢ Harder to "switch off"Hereâ€™s what helps me in making my remote job more effective:** Setting clear working hours** Taking breaks seriously (Because rest is also important to improve productivity)** Creating a separate workspace (Most helpful)** Logging off without guilt Working remotely isnâ€™t always easy â€” but itâ€™s definitely a privilege when balanced right.How do you manage work-life balance while working remotely?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#Productivity hashtag#WFH hashtag#MentalWellness hashtag#LinkedInPost



â€¦more

One of the most common myths of delocalized work is that coworkers never meet in person. Based on my own experience leading remote teams during my tenure at Microsoft, there are no substitute for meeting face to face with team members. It is actually one of the key elements to make distributed companies work! The meetings are planned and structured to allow people to come together in a way that facilitates connections in working environments where face to face time is not a continuous activity like in an office, but a well prepared and periodical activity.

Username: Hem Sharan Gupta AmarthaluriHem Sharan Gupta Amarthaluri
Post Content:
Introducing Wizzy â€” a surveillance and patrolling robot I developed as part of my Tinker Lab project, designed to work in environments where traditional CCTV systems fall short.Wizzy is more than just a mobile bot. Itâ€™s a self-thinking, self-correcting system powered by a Raspberry Pi 4 â€” capable of intelligent patrolling, real-time decision-making, and remote monitoring. Built with flexibility and scalability in mind, Wizzy is ideal for warehouses, mid-sized factories, or secure zones where both movement and memory matter.What makes Wizzy tick:1) Smart Patrol System: Avoids getting stuck, detects patterns, and makes decisions based on sensor input2) Memory of previous states and paths: Reduces repeated loops and improves efficiency over time3) Remote Surveillance: Includes a web dashboard for manual control and camera feed access4) Real-time camera monitoring: Captures and transmits visual data during patrol5) Modular codebase: Clean Python code with multithreading and behavior modelingUnder the hood: Wizzyâ€™s core logic is written in Python, using multithreading for non-blocking patrol control. The SmartPatrol engine implements a stateful decision system â€” analyzing IR sensor inputs to detect obstacles, identify stuck loops, and dynamically choose optimal turn directions. It uses pattern history (via deques), state memory, and an adaptive escape mechanism to enhance area coverage. Motion control, decision branches, and environmental feedback are abstracted for flexibility and reusability.The entire project is open-source and available here: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dY4KyM3BThis started as a college submission â€” but I see it as the first step toward practical, deployable surveillance robotics.hashtag#Robotics hashtag#Automation hashtag#Surveillance hashtag#RaspberryPi hashtag#PythonProjects hashtag#CollegeProjects hashtag#SmartSecurity hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WizzyBot hashtag#OpenSource

Here's my latest JavaFX project. The famous card game locally known as 'Daketti'.After often playing with friends till late night, I thought why not code it?Here's are its main featuresâ¡ï¸Played between four players with two in each team.â¡ï¸Game starts with 4 cards in hand of each player and 4 cards in center.â¡ï¸Excessive use of List and Stack data structures.â¡ï¸JavaFX Transition classes for animation.â¡ï¸Use of OOP principles for a scalable structure.â¡ï¸Game result calculation in the end.Currently it is played on a single PC. Future plans are to make it playable on LAN on 4 PC's using java socket programming. Also the code design focuses on all 4 OOP principles, so I have a plan to add some other card games in the collection like (local names) 'Thula', 'Bluff', etc.

What Was Patch Update 1.2.1? In our web application, version numbers carry a lot of meaning. A â€œpatchâ€ releaseâ€”in this case, 1.2.1â€”signals small but important fixes, rather than brand-new features or breaking changes. Patch 1.2.1 addressed several usability issues and visual inconsistencies that cropped up after the last minor release (1.2.0). Below is a breakdown of what we tackled and why it matters.Distinguishing This Patch from a Full Release Unlike a major or minor release, Patch 1.2.1 did not introduce new workflows or API endpoints. Instead, it focused on smoothing out rough edges in the user interface and ensuring that existing functionality behaved predictably, even under unusual conditions.1. Fixed Language Selector IssuesğŸ‘‰ Only Complete Translations Shown We now limit the dropdown to languages with full translation sets: English, Spanish, and French.ğŸ‘‰ Robust Error Handling Unsupported or partial translations no longer trigger crashes; the selector gracefully handles missing files.ğŸ‘‰ English Fallback If a userâ€™s last-selected language is removed (for example, during maintenance), the app automatically reverts to English until a supported locale is chosen.2. Added Icon-Only Behavior on ScrollğŸ‘‰ Consistent â€œStickyâ€ Behavior Much like the GitHub header, the language selector now collapses to its icon when you scroll down, freeing up space without losing accessibility.ğŸ‘‰ Improved Visibility The icon-only mode prevents the selector from obscuring content during long scrolling sessions, providing a cleaner reading experience.3. Created a Dedicated Patch Update PageğŸ‘‰ Centralized Patch Notes We spun up a new â€œPatch Updateâ€ page that documents every detail of this release in one place.ğŸ‘‰ Footer Link Access A permanently visible link in the site footer ensures you can always find the latest patch notes without hunting through changelogs.4. Improved Color ConsistencyğŸ‘‰ Theme Alignment All elements on the patch update page now adhere to our established color palette.ğŸ‘‰ CSS Variable Adoption By switching to CSS variables, future color tweaks will propagate site-wide, reducing the likelihood of mismatched hues.5. Updated DocumentationğŸ‘‰ CHANGELOG We recorded every fix and tweak under â€œ1.2.1â€ so you can trace our work from start to finish.ğŸ‘‰ Version Bump package.json now reflects the new version numberâ€”1.2.1â€”so our dependency managers and CI pipelines stay in sync.Read more here: https://lnkd.in/dRCwbFJu

Diving Deep into OpenThread Architecture forÂ STM32WB

"Yes, I still program in C when necessary. Why? Speed. And because it talks natively to the OS."Let me explain with a real-world example:I recently built a real-time WebSocket server to act as a multiplexer for users across multiple connectionsâ€”similar to how WhatsApp syncs messages between your phone and desktop browser in real-time.âœ… When a message is sent or received, it broadcasts instantly to all connected devices.âœ… But the challenge? The core project was in PHPâ€”and I needed real-time messaging without switching stacks.I tried PHP CLI to build the server, but hit a wall:â€¢ No official multithreading supportâ€¢ I had to rely on fork()â€”which creates a new process (slow & resource-heavy)â€¢ And worse: sockets couldnâ€™t be shared across processesHereâ€™s the problem:Imagine your phone is connected on Process A, your laptop on Process B.When a message arrives for your phone, Process A canâ€™t access Process Bâ€™s socket to forward it.Thatâ€™s when I turned to C.With C:â€¢ I implemented threads (sharing resources within a single process)â€¢ The socket file descriptors remained accessible across threadsâ€¢ I could handle each connection in its own thread, linked to the authenticated userHow? ğŸ‘‰ I implemented the RFC 6455 WebSocket spec for the handshake ğŸ‘‰ Then authenticated each connection by calling back to the PHP app (using the HTTP cookie) ğŸ‘‰ PHP responded with a success status and user ID, which I used to track connectionsThe result: a blazing fast, multi-threaded WebSocket server written in C, integrated seamlessly with PHP.In my next post, Iâ€™ll cover how I used IPC to connect C and PHP, and how I grouped connections in a hashmap + linked list for efficient broadcasting.ğŸ‘‰ Curious about the challenges of mixing C and PHP in real-time systems? Letâ€™s talkâ€”drop your questions below!hashtag#SystemDesign hashtag#PHP hashtag#C hashtag#Linux hashtag#WebSocket

Working with watchdog timers in RTOS systems brings interesting challenges.The basic idea is simple: the watchdog counts down and resets the system if itâ€™s not reloaded in time useful to detect infinite loops or system hangs.But in multitask systems with different deadlines (e.g., one task running every 10ms, another every 100ms), feeding the watchdog from each task becomes unreliable and messy (due to timing and concurrency issues).Some alternatives Iâ€™ve explored: - Idle-priority task feeding: Since the feeder task has the lowest priority, if any higher-priority task hangs, the watchdog wonâ€™t be fed and will eventually reset the system. - Task notification system: Each task sends an â€œIâ€™m aliveâ€ signal to a watchdog monitor. If one fails, you can react more precisely, like restart only the faulty task if a full system reset isnâ€™t necessary.While reading the hashtag#ZephyrRTOS docs, i've found a great solution called Task Watchdog:It uses kernel software timers to monitor tasks and can trigger custom callback functions when a task fails to reset its own timer. We can define per-task deadlines and recovery behavior, and still fall back to the hardware watchdog if needed.I might try this feature in my Zephyr-based cruise control system if I get the time, and if so, Iâ€™ll share some of the results.

Java 24 just dropped, and I took some of my saturday to dig into the changes compared to Java 23... And I have to say, itâ€™s a solid update. One of the things I was really looking forward to was the finalization of the Foreign Function & Memory API, it basically gives Java a safe, high-performance way to interact with native code and memory, without all the clunky, error creator boilerplate of JNI. You can now allocate off-heap memory, call native libraries, and work with memory segments almost like you're in C, but with Java safety.. I also appreciate how Java 24 is going fr preview features, like unnamed variables and patterns, not sure if they are really usefull, but I like previews, lets test it.On the tooling and performance side, the improvements to the JIT compiler and the enhancements to garbage collection are things I started seeing the impact in some memory-heavy workloads. It feels like Java is becoming a more modern language without losing what made it so stable and reliable in the first place. Iâ€™m still cautious about adopting preview features in production, but I like where things are going, itâ€™s like Java is shaking off some of its old weight while staying rock-solid for enterprise apps. Iâ€™ll definitely be using Java 24 for side projects just to explore everything more deeply.Oh, almost forgot to mention, if you wanna test the previews, use this:--enable-preview If youâ€™re using intelij, like me, youâ€™ll also need to enable preview features in the project settings.

DPDK, eBPF, and XDP: Their Crucial Roles in Virtual NetworkingIn virtual networking, DPDK, eBPF, and XDP each offer distinct advantages for optimizing performance, security, and observability. DPDK excels in high-performance, low-latency packet processing by bypassing the kernel, making it ideal for user-space network functions like virtual switches (OVS-DPDK) and virtual network functions (VNFs), where throughput and customizability are critical. eBPF, running in the kernel, enables efficient network observability, security policy enforcement, and deep packet inspection with minimal overhead. It is often integrated into Kubernetes CNI plugins like Cilium and Calico for network visibility and microsegmentation. XDP, built on top of eBPF, provides ultra-fast ingress filtering by executing programs directly at the NIC driver level, making it ideal for early packet filtering and load balancing, which reduces network congestion and latency in multi-tenant environments. Together, these technologies power modern cloud-native networks, providing high performance, flexible security, and granular control, particularly in virtualized environments like Kubernetes and NFV architectures.1. DPDKIdeal for virtual switches, VNFs, and edge compute gateways.Enables performance similar to hardware appliances.Extensively used in OpenStack and telecom NFV solutions.2. eBPF Powers Cilium, Tetragon, and other Kubernetes CNIs and observability tools.Integrates with Linux namespaces, cgroups, containers, and VMs.Extensible without kernel patches, supporting zero-trust security models.Limited performance vs DPDK in raw throughput.3. XDFIdeal for DDOS mitigation, early firewalling, and L4 load balancing.Reduces load on host networking stack yet important in multi-tenant environments.Limited programmability compared to full eBPF (no loops, tight instruction budget).Widely used in Cilium, Facebook Katran, and cloud CNI pipelines.hashtag#DPDK hashtag#eBPF hashtag#XDP hashtag#Cilium hashtag#Katran hashtag#CNI hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Tetragon hashtag#OVS

ğŸ§  Deep Dive: From Notification Failure to Protocol Insight â€“ Debugging SCTP_SEND_FAILEDIn this post, I walk through a subtle but critical SCTP issue that emerged when handling SCTP_SEND_FAILED notifications â€” exploring how low-level socket events, memory layout, and system-generated notification structures like sctp_send_failed reveal the real root cause behind failed datagram delivery in production.ğŸ” Unpacking SCTP_SEND_FAILED: From Kernel Notification to Root CauseIn SCTP-based communication systems, handling failure gracefully is as critical as achieving successful transmission. This post traces a real-world debugging session triggered by a recurring SCTP_SEND_FAILED notification â€” often dismissed as a low-level socket error, but here unpacked layer by layer to reveal deep transport-level insights.We begin at the point of failure: a datagram silently dropped, triggering a structured SCTP notification. Using sctp_send_failed and its fields (ssf_type, ssf_flags, ssf_error, and ssf_info), we decode the kernel's message about why the send operation couldn't complete. We show how to safely extract this information from a raw notification buffer, interpret the semantics of each field, and map it back to application-layer intent.To go deeper, we captured traffic with Wireshark and discovered a critical clue: a heartbeat message sent from a Docker container to our system, which unexpectedly led to the abortion of the SCTP association. This insight helped correlate the SCTP_SEND_FAILED with external traffic patterns, uncovering the real trigger â€” an out-of-band heartbeat interpreted as a protocol violation or arriving during a teardown state.By analyzing memory handling, buffer reuse, and edge-case protocol behavior (like full receive queues or association termination), we arrived at a concrete cause â€” often buried deep beneath user-facing symptoms. This is a story of system-level observability, correct struct alignment, and mastering the contract between user space and kernel through precise data interpretation.Ideal for engineers working with SCTP, E2AP, or any protocol stack that depends on robust notification handling.Iâ€™d be glad to collaborate on any projects in the fields of telecommunications systems, wireless networks, network protocols, or low-level programming. If you believe my experience and skills can contribute to your work, Iâ€™d be more than happy to be part of your team â€” even in a small role.

Balancing work and personal life is no easy task.Even with a carefully planned to-do list, thereâ€™s always something left unchecked, a call to return, a workout missed, or a hobby postponed.As someone working a full-time remote job, Iâ€™ve experienced both sides of the coin.Many assume remote work is all about comfort, no commute, flexible hours, more time with family. Introducing Wizzy â€” a surveillance and patrolling robot I developed as part of my Tinker Lab project, designed to work in environments where traditional CCTV systems fall short.Wizzy is more than just a mobile bot. Itâ€™s a self-thinking, self-correcting system powered by a Raspberry Pi 4 â€” capable of intelligent patrolling, real-time decision-making, and remote monitoring. Built with flexibility and scalability in mind, Wizzy is ideal for warehouses, mid-sized factories, or secure zones where both movement and memory matter.What makes Wizzy tick:1) Smart Patrol System: Avoids getting stuck, detects patterns, and makes decisions based on sensor input2) Memory of previous states and paths: Reduces repeated loops and improves efficiency over time3) Remote Surveillance: Includes a web dashboard for manual control and camera feed access4) Real-time camera monitoring: Captures and transmits visual data during patrol5) Modular codebase: Clean Python code with multithreading and behavior modelingUnder the hood: Wizzyâ€™s core logic is written in Python, using multithreading for non-blocking patrol control. The SmartPatrol engine implements a stateful decision system â€” analyzing IR sensor inputs to detect obstacles, identify stuck loops, and dynamically choose optimal turn directions. It uses pattern history (via deques), state memory, and an adaptive escape mechanism to enhance area coverage. Motion control, decision branches, and environmental feedback are abstracted for flexibility and reusability.The entire project is open-source and available here: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dY4KyM3BThis started as a college submission â€” but I see it as the first step toward practical, deployable surveillance robotics.hashtag#Robotics hashtag#Automation hashtag#Surveillance hashtag#RaspberryPi hashtag#PythonProjects hashtag#CollegeProjects hashtag#SmartSecurity hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WizzyBot hashtag#OpenSource

Here's my latest JavaFX project. The famous card game locally known as 'Daketti'.After often playing with friends till late night, I thought why not code it?Here's are its main featuresâ¡ï¸Played between four players with two in each team.â¡ï¸Game starts with 4 cards in hand of each player and 4 cards in center.â¡ï¸Excessive use of List and Stack data structures.â¡ï¸JavaFX Transition classes for animation.â¡ï¸Use of OOP principles for a scalable structure.â¡ï¸Game result calculation in the end.Currently it is played on a single PC. Future plans are to make it playable on LAN on 4 PC's using java socket programming. Also the code design focuses on all 4 OOP principles, so I have a plan to add some other card games in the collection like (local names) 'Thula', 'Bluff', etc.

What Was Patch Update 1.2.1? In our web application, version numbers carry a lot of meaning. A â€œpatchâ€ releaseâ€”in this case, 1.2.1â€”signals small but important fixes, rather than brand-new features or breaking changes. Patch 1.2.1 addressed several usability issues and visual inconsistencies that cropped up after the last minor release (1.2.0). Below is a breakdown of what we tackled and why it matters.Distinguishing This Patch from a Full Release Unlike a major or minor release, Patch 1.2.1 did not introduce new workflows or API endpoints. Instead, it focused on smoothing out rough edges in the user interface and ensuring that existing functionality behaved predictably, even under unusual conditions.1. Fixed Language Selector IssuesğŸ‘‰ Only Complete Translations Shown We now limit the dropdown to languages with full translation sets: English, Spanish, and French.ğŸ‘‰ Robust Error Handling Unsupported or partial translations no longer trigger crashes; the selector gracefully handles missing files.ğŸ‘‰ English Fallback If a userâ€™s last-selected language is removed (for example, during maintenance), the app automatically reverts to English until a supported locale is chosen.2. Added Icon-Only Behavior on ScrollğŸ‘‰ Consistent â€œStickyâ€ Behavior Much like the GitHub header, the language selector now collapses to its icon when you scroll down, freeing up space without losing accessibility.ğŸ‘‰ Improved Visibility The icon-only mode prevents the selector from obscuring content during long scrolling sessions, providing a cleaner reading experience.3. Created a Dedicated Patch Update PageğŸ‘‰ Centralized Patch Notes We spun up a new â€œPatch Updateâ€ page that documents every detail of this release in one place.ğŸ‘‰ Footer Link Access A permanently visible link in the site footer ensures you can always find the latest patch notes without hunting through changelogs.4. Improved Color ConsistencyğŸ‘‰ Theme Alignment All elements on the patch update page now adhere to our established color palette.ğŸ‘‰ CSS Variable Adoption By switching to CSS variables, future color tweaks will propagate site-wide, reducing the likelihood of mismatched hues.5. Updated DocumentationğŸ‘‰ CHANGELOG We recorded every fix and tweak under â€œ1.2.1â€ so you can trace our work from start to finish.ğŸ‘‰ Version Bump package.json now reflects the new version numberâ€”1.2.1â€”so our dependency managers and CI pipelines stay in sync.Read more here: https://lnkd.in/dRCwbFJu

ğŸŒ™ Evening Tip for Remote Workers: The #1 Customer Service Hack.Working remotely? Hereâ€™s a game-changer for delivering exceptional customer service: **"Listen first, solve second."** In a digital world, customers crave genuine connection. Before jumping to solutions: âœ” **Acknowledge their concern** â€“ "I understand how frustrating this must be." âœ” **Clarify before assuming** â€“ "Just to confirm, are you facing [specific issue]?" âœ” **Then, resolve with confidence.** Why? Because people donâ€™t just want fixesâ€”they want to feel *heard*. **Pro Remote Bonus:** Use short, empathetic voice notes (when appropriate) to add a human touch to written chats. ğŸ™ï¸ Whatâ€™s your go-to remote customer service tip? Diving Deep into OpenThread Architecture forÂ STM32WB

"Yes, I still program in C when necessary. Why? Speed. And because it talks natively to the OS."Let me explain with a real-world example:I recently built a real-time WebSocket server to act as a multiplexer for users across multiple connectionsâ€”similar to how WhatsApp syncs messages between your phone and desktop browser in real-time.âœ… When a message is sent or received, it broadcasts instantly to all connected devices.âœ… But the challenge? The core project was in PHPâ€”and I needed real-time messaging without switching stacks.I tried PHP CLI to build the server, but hit a wall:â€¢ No official multithreading supportâ€¢ I had to rely on fork()â€”which creates a new process (slow & resource-heavy)â€¢ And worse: sockets couldnâ€™t be shared across processesHereâ€™s the problem:Imagine your phone is connected on Process A, your laptop on Process B.When a message arrives for your phone, Process A canâ€™t access Process Bâ€™s socket to forward it.Thatâ€™s when I turned to C.With C:â€¢ I implemented threads (sharing resources within a single process)â€¢ The socket file descriptors remained accessible across threadsâ€¢ I could handle each connection in its own thread, linked to the authenticated userHow? ğŸ‘‰ I implemented the RFC 6455 WebSocket spec for the handshake ğŸ‘‰ Then authenticated each connection by calling back to the PHP app (using the HTTP cookie) ğŸ‘‰ PHP responded with a success status and user ID, which I used to track connectionsThe result: a blazing fast, multi-threaded WebSocket server written in C, integrated seamlessly with PHP.In my next post, Iâ€™ll cover how I used IPC to connect C and PHP, and how I grouped connections in a hashmap + linked list for efficient broadcasting.ğŸ‘‰ Curious about the challenges of mixing C and PHP in real-time systems? Letâ€™s talkâ€”drop your questions below!hashtag#SystemDesign hashtag#PHP hashtag#C hashtag#Linux hashtag#WebSocket

As mentioned,Â fine graned authorization for metrics. The POC I am building is based upon cerbos (cerbos.dev).Assuming we have either a centralized or many distributed Thanos/Prometheus endpoints to fetch metrics from and the user utilized one observability UI. Adding such a Authorization proxy can simplify what people can see in the sense of being able to drill down to more than just label==prom-label-proxy value...I've recorded a short demo showing two interfaces (Grafana & Perses) accessing a centralized Prometheus Store without any tenancy knowledge. The Queries shown are taken, examined (and since I run no tenancy, remove the tenant= label) and processed with the backend. In the functional query (rate, implemented as Feature policy meaning you can enable/disable features like that per policy) the permissions for the user executing need to be satisfied on any provided parameter and further more also on any returned metric label (which why the same query with switching tenant=namespace1 to namespace=superuser reveals an additional label metric as namespace1 lacks permissions to view /daniel as label path in the metric requests_total.I am trying to push a POC for everyone to be evaluated soon but right now any additional ideas you can think of are highly appreciated ...

Working with watchdog timers in RTOS systems brings interesting challenges.The basic idea is simple: the watchdog counts down and resets the system if itâ€™s not reloaded in time useful to detect infinite loops or system hangs.But in multitask systems with different deadlines (e.g., one task running every 10ms, another every 100ms), feeding the watchdog from each task becomes unreliable and messy (due to timing and concurrency issues).Some alternatives Iâ€™ve explored: - Idle-priority task feeding: Since the feeder task has the lowest priority, if any higher-priority task hangs, the watchdog wonâ€™t be fed and will eventually reset the system. - Task notification system: Each task sends an â€œIâ€™m aliveâ€ signal to a watchdog monitor. If one fails, you can react more precisely, like restart only the faulty task if a full system reset isnâ€™t necessary.While reading the hashtag#ZephyrRTOS docs, i've found a great solution called Task Watchdog:It uses kernel software timers to monitor tasks and can trigger custom callback functions when a task fails to reset its own timer. We can define per-task deadlines and recovery behavior, and still fall back to the hardware watchdog if needed.I might try this feature in my Zephyr-based cruise control system if I get the time, and if so, Iâ€™ll share some of the results.

Java 24 just dropped, and I took some of my saturday to dig into the changes compared to Java 23... And I have to say, itâ€™s a solid update. One of the things I was really looking forward to was the finalization of the Foreign Function & Memory API, it basically gives Java a safe, high-performance way to interact with native code and memory, without all the clunky, error creator boilerplate of JNI. You can now allocate off-heap memory, call native libraries, and work with memory segments almost like you're in C, but with Java safety.. I also appreciate how Java 24 is going fr preview features, like unnamed variables and patterns, not sure if they are really usefull, but I like previews, lets test it.On the tooling and performance side, the improvements to the JIT compiler and the enhancements to garbage collection are things I started seeing the impact in some memory-heavy workloads. It feels like Java is becoming a more modern language without losing what made it so stable and reliable in the first place. Iâ€™m still cautious about adopting preview features in production, but I like where things are going, itâ€™s like Java is shaking off some of its old weight while staying rock-solid for enterprise apps. Iâ€™ll definitely be using Java 24 for side projects just to explore everything more deeply.Oh, almost forgot to mention, if you wanna test the previews, use this:--enable-preview If youâ€™re using intelij, like me, youâ€™ll also need to enable preview features in the project settings.

DPDK, eBPF, and XDP: Their Crucial Roles in Virtual NetworkingIn virtual networking, DPDK, eBPF, and XDP each offer distinct advantages for optimizing performance, security, and observability. DPDK excels in high-performance, low-latency packet processing by bypassing the kernel, making it ideal for user-space network functions like virtual switches (OVS-DPDK) and virtual network functions (VNFs), where throughput and customizability are critical. eBPF, running in the kernel, enables efficient network observability, security policy enforcement, and deep packet inspection with minimal overhead. It is often integrated into Kubernetes CNI plugins like Cilium and Calico for network visibility and microsegmentation. XDP, built on top of eBPF, provides ultra-fast ingress filtering by executing programs directly at the NIC driver level, making it ideal for early packet filtering and load balancing, which reduces network congestion and latency in multi-tenant environments. Together, these technologies power modern cloud-native networks, providing high performance, flexible security, and granular control, particularly in virtualized environments like Kubernetes and NFV architectures.1. DPDKIdeal for virtual switches, VNFs, and edge compute gateways.Enables performance similar to hardware appliances.Extensively used in OpenStack and telecom NFV solutions.2. eBPF Powers Cilium, Tetragon, and other Kubernetes CNIs and observability tools.Integrates with Linux namespaces, cgroups, containers, and VMs.Extensible without kernel patches, supporting zero-trust security models.Limited performance vs DPDK in raw throughput.3. XDFIdeal for DDOS mitigation, early firewalling, and L4 load balancing.Reduces load on host networking stack yet important in multi-tenant environments.Limited programmability compared to full eBPF (no loops, tight instruction budget).Widely used in Cilium, Facebook Katran, and cloud CNI pipelines.hashtag#DPDK hashtag#eBPF hashtag#XDP hashtag#Cilium hashtag#Katran hashtag#CNI hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Tetragon hashtag#OVS

ğŸ§  Deep Dive: From Notification Failure to Protocol Insight â€“ Debugging SCTP_SEND_FAILEDIn this post, I walk through a subtle but critical SCTP issue that emerged when handling SCTP_SEND_FAILED notifications â€” exploring how low-level socket events, memory layout, and system-generated notification structures like sctp_send_failed reveal the real root cause behind failed datagram delivery in production.ğŸ” Unpacking SCTP_SEND_FAILED: From Kernel Notification to Root CauseIn SCTP-based communication systems, handling failure gracefully is as critical as achieving successful transmission. This post traces a real-world debugging session triggered by a recurring SCTP_SEND_FAILED notification â€” often dismissed as a low-level socket error, but here unpacked layer by layer to reveal deep transport-level insights.We begin at the point of failure: a datagram silently dropped, triggering a structured SCTP notification. Using sctp_send_failed and its fields (ssf_type, ssf_flags, ssf_error, and ssf_info), we decode the kernel's message about why the send operation couldn't complete. We show how to safely extract this information from a raw notification buffer, interpret the semantics of each field, and map it back to application-layer intent.To go deeper, we captured traffic with Wireshark and discovered a critical clue: a heartbeat message sent from a Docker container to our system, which unexpectedly led to the abortion of the SCTP association. This insight helped correlate the SCTP_SEND_FAILED with external traffic patterns, uncovering the real trigger â€” an out-of-band heartbeat interpreted as a protocol violation or arriving during a teardown state.By analyzing memory handling, buffer reuse, and edge-case protocol behavior (like full receive queues or association termination), we arrived at a concrete cause â€” often buried deep beneath user-facing symptoms. This is a story of system-level observability, correct struct alignment, and mastering the contract between user space and kernel through precise data interpretation.Ideal for engineers working with SCTP, E2AP, or any protocol stack that depends on robust notification handling.Iâ€™d be glad to collaborate on any projects in the fields of telecommunications systems, wireless networks, network protocols, or low-level programming. If you believe my experience and skills can contribute to your work, Iâ€™d be more than happy to be part of your team â€” even in a small role.

One of the most common myths of delocalized work is that coworkers never meet in person. Based on my own experience leading remote teams during my tenure at Microsoft, there are no substitute for meeting face to face with team members. It is actually one of the key elements to make distributed companies work! The meetings are planned and structured to allow people to come together in a way that facilitates connections in working environments where face to face time is not a continuous activity like in an office, but a well prepared and periodical activity.

Introducing Wizzy â€” a surveillance and patrolling robot I developed as part of my Tinker Lab project, designed to work in environments where traditional CCTV systems fall short.Wizzy is more than just a mobile bot. Itâ€™s a self-thinking, self-correcting system powered by a Raspberry Pi 4 â€” capable of intelligent patrolling, real-time decision-making, and remote monitoring. Built with flexibility and scalability in mind, Wizzy is ideal for warehouses, mid-sized factories, or secure zones where both movement and memory matter.What makes Wizzy tick:1) Smart Patrol System: Avoids getting stuck, detects patterns, and makes decisions based on sensor input2) Memory of previous states and paths: Reduces repeated loops and improves efficiency over time3) Remote Surveillance: Includes a web dashboard for manual control and camera feed access4) Real-time camera monitoring: Captures and transmits visual data during patrol5) Modular codebase: Clean Python code with multithreading and behavior modelingUnder the hood: Wizzyâ€™s core logic is written in Python, using multithreading for non-blocking patrol control. The SmartPatrol engine implements a stateful decision system â€” analyzing IR sensor inputs to detect obstacles, identify stuck loops, and dynamically choose optimal turn directions. It uses pattern history (via deques), state memory, and an adaptive escape mechanism to enhance area coverage. Motion control, decision branches, and environmental feedback are abstracted for flexibility and reusability.The entire project is open-source and available here: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dY4KyM3BThis started as a college submission â€” but I see it as the first step toward practical, deployable surveillance robotics.hashtag#Robotics hashtag#Automation hashtag#Surveillance hashtag#RaspberryPi hashtag#PythonProjects hashtag#CollegeProjects hashtag#SmartSecurity hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WizzyBot hashtag#OpenSource

Here's my latest JavaFX project. The famous card game locally known as 'Daketti'.After often playing with friends till late night, I thought why not code it?Here's are its main featuresâ¡ï¸Played between four players with two in each team.â¡ï¸Game starts with 4 cards in hand of each player and 4 cards in center.â¡ï¸Excessive use of List and Stack data structures.â¡ï¸JavaFX Transition classes for animation.â¡ï¸Use of OOP principles for a scalable structure.â¡ï¸Game result calculation in the end.Currently it is played on a single PC. Future plans are to make it playable on LAN on 4 PC's using java socket programming. Also the code design focuses on all 4 OOP principles, so I have a plan to add some other card games in the collection like (local names) 'Thula', 'Bluff', etc.

What Was Patch Update 1.2.1? In our web application, version numbers carry a lot of meaning. A â€œpatchâ€ releaseâ€”in this case, 1.2.1â€”signals small but important fixes, rather than brand-new features or breaking changes. Patch 1.2.1 addressed several usability issues and visual inconsistencies that cropped up after the last minor release (1.2.0). Below is a breakdown of what we tackled and why it matters.Distinguishing This Patch from a Full Release Unlike a major or minor release, Patch 1.2.1 did not introduce new workflows or API endpoints. Instead, it focused on smoothing out rough edges in the user interface and ensuring that existing functionality behaved predictably, even under unusual conditions.1. Fixed Language Selector IssuesğŸ‘‰ Only Complete Translations Shown We now limit the dropdown to languages with full translation sets: English, Spanish, and French.ğŸ‘‰ Robust Error Handling Unsupported or partial translations no longer trigger crashes; the selector gracefully handles missing files.ğŸ‘‰ English Fallback If a userâ€™s last-selected language is removed (for example, during maintenance), the app automatically reverts to English until a supported locale is chosen.2. Added Icon-Only Behavior on ScrollğŸ‘‰ Consistent â€œStickyâ€ Behavior Much like the GitHub header, the language selector now collapses to its icon when you scroll down, freeing up space without losing accessibility.ğŸ‘‰ Improved Visibility The icon-only mode prevents the selector from obscuring content during long scrolling sessions, providing a cleaner reading experience.3. Created a Dedicated Patch Update PageğŸ‘‰ Centralized Patch Notes We spun up a new â€œPatch Updateâ€ page that documents every detail of this release in one place.ğŸ‘‰ Footer Link Access A permanently visible link in the site footer ensures you can always find the latest patch notes without hunting through changelogs.4. Improved Color ConsistencyğŸ‘‰ Theme Alignment All elements on the patch update page now adhere to our established color palette.ğŸ‘‰ CSS Variable Adoption By switching to CSS variables, future color tweaks will propagate site-wide, reducing the likelihood of mismatched hues.5. Updated DocumentationğŸ‘‰ CHANGELOG We recorded every fix and tweak under â€œ1.2.1â€ so you can trace our work from start to finish.ğŸ‘‰ Version Bump package.json now reflects the new version numberâ€”1.2.1â€”so our dependency managers and CI pipelines stay in sync.Read more here: https://lnkd.in/dRCwbFJu

ğŸŒ™ Evening Tip for Remote Workers: The #1 Customer Service Hack.Working remotely? Hereâ€™s a game-changer for delivering exceptional customer service: **"Listen first, solve second."** In a digital world, customers crave genuine connection. Before jumping to solutions: âœ” **Acknowledge their concern** â€“ "I understand how frustrating this must be." âœ” **Clarify before assuming** â€“ "Just to confirm, are you facing [specific issue]?" âœ” **Then, resolve with confidence.** Why? Because people donâ€™t just want fixesâ€”they want to feel *heard*. **Pro Remote Bonus:** Use short, empathetic voice notes (when appropriate) to add a human touch to written chats. ğŸ™ï¸ Whatâ€™s your go-to remote customer service tip? Diving Deep into OpenThread Architecture forÂ STM32WB

"Yes, I still program in C when necessary. Why? Speed. And because it talks natively to the OS."Let me explain with a real-world example:I recently built a real-time WebSocket server to act as a multiplexer for users across multiple connectionsâ€”similar to how WhatsApp syncs messages between your phone and desktop browser in real-time.âœ… When a message is sent or received, it broadcasts instantly to all connected devices.âœ… But the challenge? The core project was in PHPâ€”and I needed real-time messaging without switching stacks.I tried PHP CLI to build the server, but hit a wall:â€¢ No official multithreading supportâ€¢ I had to rely on fork()â€”which creates a new process (slow & resource-heavy)â€¢ And worse: sockets couldnâ€™t be shared across processesHereâ€™s the problem:Imagine your phone is connected on Process A, your laptop on Process B.When a message arrives for your phone, Process A canâ€™t access Process Bâ€™s socket to forward it.Thatâ€™s when I turned to C.With C:â€¢ I implemented threads (sharing resources within a single process)â€¢ The socket file descriptors remained accessible across threadsâ€¢ I could handle each connection in its own thread, linked to the authenticated userHow? ğŸ‘‰ I implemented the RFC 6455 WebSocket spec for the handshake ğŸ‘‰ Then authenticated each connection by calling back to the PHP app (using the HTTP cookie) ğŸ‘‰ PHP responded with a success status and user ID, which I used to track connectionsThe result: a blazing fast, multi-threaded WebSocket server written in C, integrated seamlessly with PHP.In my next post, Iâ€™ll cover how I used IPC to connect C and PHP, and how I grouped connections in a hashmap + linked list for efficient broadcasting.ğŸ‘‰ Curious about the challenges of mixing C and PHP in real-time systems? Letâ€™s talkâ€”drop your questions below!hashtag#SystemDesign hashtag#PHP hashtag#C hashtag#Linux hashtag#WebSocket

As mentioned,Â fine graned authorization for metrics. The POC I am building is based upon cerbos (cerbos.dev).Assuming we have either a centralized or many distributed Thanos/Prometheus endpoints to fetch metrics from and the user utilized one observability UI. Adding such a Authorization proxy can simplify what people can see in the sense of being able to drill down to more than just label==prom-label-proxy value...I've recorded a short demo showing two interfaces (Grafana & Perses) accessing a centralized Prometheus Store without any tenancy knowledge. The Queries shown are taken, examined (and since I run no tenancy, remove the tenant= label) and processed with the backend. In the functional query (rate, implemented as Feature policy meaning you can enable/disable features like that per policy) the permissions for the user executing need to be satisfied on any provided parameter and further more also on any returned metric label (which why the same query with switching tenant=namespace1 to namespace=superuser reveals an additional label metric as namespace1 lacks permissions to view /daniel as label path in the metric requests_total.I am trying to push a POC for everyone to be evaluated soon but right now any additional ideas you can think of are highly appreciated ...

Working with watchdog timers in RTOS systems brings interesting challenges.The basic idea is simple: the watchdog counts down and resets the system if itâ€™s not reloaded in time useful to detect infinite loops or system hangs.But in multitask systems with different deadlines (e.g., one task running every 10ms, another every 100ms), feeding the watchdog from each task becomes unreliable and messy (due to timing and concurrency issues).Some alternatives Iâ€™ve explored: - Idle-priority task feeding: Since the feeder task has the lowest priority, if any higher-priority task hangs, the watchdog wonâ€™t be fed and will eventually reset the system. - Task notification system: Each task sends an â€œIâ€™m aliveâ€ signal to a watchdog monitor. If one fails, you can react more precisely, like restart only the faulty task if a full system reset isnâ€™t necessary.While reading the hashtag#ZephyrRTOS docs, i've found a great solution called Task Watchdog:It uses kernel software timers to monitor tasks and can trigger custom callback functions when a task fails to reset its own timer. We can define per-task deadlines and recovery behavior, and still fall back to the hardware watchdog if needed.I might try this feature in my Zephyr-based cruise control system if I get the time, and if so, Iâ€™ll share some of the results.

Java 24 just dropped, and I took some of my saturday to dig into the changes compared to Java 23... And I have to say, itâ€™s a solid update. One of the things I was really looking forward to was the finalization of the Foreign Function & Memory API, it basically gives Java a safe, high-performance way to interact with native code and memory, without all the clunky, error creator boilerplate of JNI. You can now allocate off-heap memory, call native libraries, and work with memory segments almost like you're in C, but with Java safety.. I also appreciate how Java 24 is going fr preview features, like unnamed variables and patterns, not sure if they are really usefull, but I like previews, lets test it.On the tooling and performance side, the improvements to the JIT compiler and the enhancements to garbage collection are things I started seeing the impact in some memory-heavy workloads. It feels like Java is becoming a more modern language without losing what made it so stable and reliable in the first place. Iâ€™m still cautious about adopting preview features in production, but I like where things are going, itâ€™s like Java is shaking off some of its old weight while staying rock-solid for enterprise apps. Iâ€™ll definitely be using Java 24 for side projects just to explore everything more deeply.Oh, almost forgot to mention, if you wanna test the previews, use this:--enable-preview If youâ€™re using intelij, like me, youâ€™ll also need to enable preview features in the project settings.

DPDK, eBPF, and XDP: Their Crucial Roles in Virtual NetworkingIn virtual networking, DPDK, eBPF, and XDP each offer distinct advantages for optimizing performance, security, and observability. DPDK excels in high-performance, low-latency packet processing by bypassing the kernel, making it ideal for user-space network functions like virtual switches (OVS-DPDK) and virtual network functions (VNFs), where throughput and customizability are critical. eBPF, running in the kernel, enables efficient network observability, security policy enforcement, and deep packet inspection with minimal overhead. It is often integrated into Kubernetes CNI plugins like Cilium and Calico for network visibility and microsegmentation. XDP, built on top of eBPF, provides ultra-fast ingress filtering by executing programs directly at the NIC driver level, making it ideal for early packet filtering and load balancing, which reduces network congestion and latency in multi-tenant environments. Together, these technologies power modern cloud-native networks, providing high performance, flexible security, and granular control, particularly in virtualized environments like Kubernetes and NFV architectures.1. DPDKIdeal for virtual switches, VNFs, and edge compute gateways.Enables performance similar to hardware appliances.Extensively used in OpenStack and telecom NFV solutions.2. eBPF Powers Cilium, Tetragon, and other Kubernetes CNIs and observability tools.Integrates with Linux namespaces, cgroups, containers, and VMs.Extensible without kernel patches, supporting zero-trust security models.Limited performance vs DPDK in raw throughput.3. XDFIdeal for DDOS mitigation, early firewalling, and L4 load balancing.Reduces load on host networking stack yet important in multi-tenant environments.Limited programmability compared to full eBPF (no loops, tight instruction budget).Widely used in Cilium, Facebook Katran, and cloud CNI pipelines.hashtag#DPDK hashtag#eBPF hashtag#XDP hashtag#Cilium hashtag#Katran hashtag#CNI hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Tetragon hashtag#OVS

ğŸ§  Deep Dive: From Notification Failure to Protocol Insight â€“ Debugging SCTP_SEND_FAILEDIn this post, I walk through a subtle but critical SCTP issue that emerged when handling SCTP_SEND_FAILED notifications â€” exploring how low-level socket events, memory layout, and system-generated notification structures like sctp_send_failed reveal the real root cause behind failed datagram delivery in production.ğŸ” Unpacking SCTP_SEND_FAILED: From Kernel Notification to Root CauseIn SCTP-based communication systems, handling failure gracefully is as critical as achieving successful transmission. This post traces a real-world debugging session triggered by a recurring SCTP_SEND_FAILED notification â€” often dismissed as a low-level socket error, but here unpacked layer by layer to reveal deep transport-level insights.We begin at the point of failure: a datagram silently dropped, triggering a structured SCTP notification. Using sctp_send_failed and its fields (ssf_type, ssf_flags, ssf_error, and ssf_info), we decode the kernel's message about why the send operation couldn't complete. We show how to safely extract this information from a raw notification buffer, interpret the semantics of each field, and map it back to application-layer intent.To go deeper, we captured traffic with Wireshark and discovered a critical clue: a heartbeat message sent from a Docker container to our system, which unexpectedly led to the abortion of the SCTP association. This insight helped correlate the SCTP_SEND_FAILED with external traffic patterns, uncovering the real trigger â€” an out-of-band heartbeat interpreted as a protocol violation or arriving during a teardown state.By analyzing memory handling, buffer reuse, and edge-case protocol behavior (like full receive queues or association termination), we arrived at a concrete cause â€” often buried deep beneath user-facing symptoms. This is a story of system-level observability, correct struct alignment, and mastering the contract between user space and kernel through precise data interpretation.Ideal for engineers working with SCTP, E2AP, or any protocol stack that depends on robust notification handling.Iâ€™d be glad to collaborate on any projects in the fields of telecommunications systems, wireless networks, network protocols, or low-level programming. If you believe my experience and skills can contribute to your work, Iâ€™d be more than happy to be part of your team â€” even in a small role.

One of the most common myths of delocalized work is that coworkers never meet in person. Based on my own experience leading remote teams during my tenure at Microsoft, there are no substitute for meeting face to face with team members. It is actually one of the key elements to make distributed companies work! The meetings are planned and structured to allow people to come together in a way that facilitates connections in working environments where face to face time is not a continuous activity like in an office, but a well prepared and periodical activity.

Introducing Wizzy â€” a surveillance and patrolling robot I developed as part of my Tinker Lab project, designed to work in environments where traditional CCTV systems fall short.Wizzy is more than just a mobile bot. Itâ€™s a self-thinking, self-correcting system powered by a Raspberry Pi 4 â€” capable of intelligent patrolling, real-time decision-making, and remote monitoring. Built with flexibility and scalability in mind, Wizzy is ideal for warehouses, mid-sized factories, or secure zones where both movement and memory matter.What makes Wizzy tick:1) Smart Patrol System: Avoids getting stuck, detects patterns, and makes decisions based on sensor input2) Memory of previous states and paths: Reduces repeated loops and improves efficiency over time3) Remote Surveillance: Includes a web dashboard for manual control and camera feed access4) Real-time camera monitoring: Captures and transmits visual data during patrol5) Modular codebase: Clean Python code with multithreading and behavior modelingUnder the hood: Wizzyâ€™s core logic is written in Python, using multithreading for non-blocking patrol control. The SmartPatrol engine implements a stateful decision system â€” analyzing IR sensor inputs to detect obstacles, identify stuck loops, and dynamically choose optimal turn directions. It uses pattern history (via deques), state memory, and an adaptive escape mechanism to enhance area coverage. Motion control, decision branches, and environmental feedback are abstracted for flexibility and reusability.The entire project is open-source and available here: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dY4KyM3BThis started as a college submission â€” but I see it as the first step toward practical, deployable surveillance robotics.hashtag#Robotics hashtag#Automation hashtag#Surveillance hashtag#RaspberryPi hashtag#PythonProjects hashtag#CollegeProjects hashtag#SmartSecurity hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WizzyBot hashtag#OpenSource

Here's my latest JavaFX project. The famous card game locally known as 'Daketti'.After often playing with friends till late night, I thought why not code it?Here's are its main featuresâ¡ï¸Played between four players with two in each team.â¡ï¸Game starts with 4 cards in hand of each player and 4 cards in center.â¡ï¸Excessive use of List and Stack data structures.â¡ï¸JavaFX Transition classes for animation.â¡ï¸Use of OOP principles for a scalable structure.â¡ï¸Game result calculation in the end.Currently it is played on a single PC. Future plans are to make it playable on LAN on 4 PC's using java socket programming. Also the code design focuses on all 4 OOP principles, so I have a plan to add some other card games in the collection like (local names) 'Thula', 'Bluff', etc.

What Was Patch Update 1.2.1? In our web application, version numbers carry a lot of meaning. A â€œpatchâ€ releaseâ€”in this case, 1.2.1â€”signals small but important fixes, rather than brand-new features or breaking changes. Patch 1.2.1 addressed several usability issues and visual inconsistencies that cropped up after the last minor release (1.2.0). Below is a breakdown of what we tackled and why it matters.Distinguishing This Patch from a Full Release Unlike a major or minor release, Patch 1.2.1 did not introduce new workflows or API endpoints. Instead, it focused on smoothing out rough edges in the user interface and ensuring that existing functionality behaved predictably, even under unusual conditions.1. Fixed Language Selector IssuesğŸ‘‰ Only Complete Translations Shown We now limit the dropdown to languages with full translation sets: English, Spanish, and French.ğŸ‘‰ Robust Error Handling Unsupported or partial translations no longer trigger crashes; the selector gracefully handles missing files.ğŸ‘‰ English Fallback If a userâ€™s last-selected language is removed (for example, during maintenance), the app automatically reverts to English until a supported locale is chosen.2. Added Icon-Only Behavior on ScrollğŸ‘‰ Consistent â€œStickyâ€ Behavior Much like the GitHub header, the language selector now collapses to its icon when you scroll down, freeing up space without losing accessibility.ğŸ‘‰ Improved Visibility The icon-only mode prevents the selector from obscuring content during long scrolling sessions, providing a cleaner reading experience.3. Created a Dedicated Patch Update PageğŸ‘‰ Centralized Patch Notes We spun up a new â€œPatch Updateâ€ page that documents every detail of this release in one place.ğŸ‘‰ Footer Link Access A permanently visible link in the site footer ensures you can always find the latest patch notes without hunting through changelogs.4. Improved Color ConsistencyğŸ‘‰ Theme Alignment All elements on the patch update page now adhere to our established color palette.ğŸ‘‰ CSS Variable Adoption By switching to CSS variables, future color tweaks will propagate site-wide, reducing the likelihood of mismatched hues.5. Updated DocumentationğŸ‘‰ CHANGELOG We recorded every fix and tweak under â€œ1.2.1â€ so you can trace our work from start to finish.ğŸ‘‰ Version Bump package.json now reflects the new version numberâ€”1.2.1â€”so our dependency managers and CI pipelines stay in sync.Read more here: https://lnkd.in/dRCwbFJu

ğŸŒ™ Evening Tip for Remote Workers: The #1 Customer Service Hack.Working remotely? Hereâ€™s a game-changer for delivering exceptional customer service: **"Listen first, solve second."** In a digital world, customers crave genuine connection. Before jumping to solutions: âœ” **Acknowledge their concern** â€“ "I understand how frustrating this must be." âœ” **Clarify before assuming** â€“ "Just to confirm, are you facing [specific issue]?" âœ” **Then, resolve with confidence.** Why? Because people donâ€™t just want fixesâ€”they want to feel *heard*. **Pro Remote Bonus:** Use short, empathetic voice notes (when appropriate) to add a human touch to written chats. ğŸ™ï¸ Whatâ€™s your go-to remote customer service tip? Diving Deep into OpenThread Architecture forÂ STM32WB

"Yes, I still program in C when necessary. Why? Speed. And because it talks natively to the OS."Let me explain with a real-world example:I recently built a real-time WebSocket server to act as a multiplexer for users across multiple connectionsâ€”similar to how WhatsApp syncs messages between your phone and desktop browser in real-time.âœ… When a message is sent or received, it broadcasts instantly to all connected devices.âœ… But the challenge? The core project was in PHPâ€”and I needed real-time messaging without switching stacks.I tried PHP CLI to build the server, but hit a wall:â€¢ No official multithreading supportâ€¢ I had to rely on fork()â€”which creates a new process (slow & resource-heavy)â€¢ And worse: sockets couldnâ€™t be shared across processesHereâ€™s the problem:Imagine your phone is connected on Process A, your laptop on Process B.When a message arrives for your phone, Process A canâ€™t access Process Bâ€™s socket to forward it.Thatâ€™s when I turned to C.With C:â€¢ I implemented threads (sharing resources within a single process)â€¢ The socket file descriptors remained accessible across threadsâ€¢ I could handle each connection in its own thread, linked to the authenticated userHow? ğŸ‘‰ I implemented the RFC 6455 WebSocket spec for the handshake ğŸ‘‰ Then authenticated each connection by calling back to the PHP app (using the HTTP cookie) ğŸ‘‰ PHP responded with a success status and user ID, which I used to track connectionsThe result: a blazing fast, multi-threaded WebSocket server written in C, integrated seamlessly with PHP.In my next post, Iâ€™ll cover how I used IPC to connect C and PHP, and how I grouped connections in a hashmap + linked list for efficient broadcasting.ğŸ‘‰ Curious about the challenges of mixing C and PHP in real-time systems? Letâ€™s talkâ€”drop your questions below!hashtag#SystemDesign hashtag#PHP hashtag#C hashtag#Linux hashtag#WebSocket
